bugs.title: ftdi_sio: new icp das i7561u usb-serial converter needs vid/pid entry

bugzilla.short_desc: ftdi_sio: new icp das i7561u usb-serial converter needs vid/pid entry

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
The i7561u converter works fine with ftdi_sio driver if it's vid/pid is added to id_table_combined array (drivers/usb/serial/ftdi_sio.c: line 142). They are 0x1b5c (vid), 0x0104 (pid). Please add them to the list, no other modifications required (at least I didn't notice anything wrong while testing). I suspect that there are more 756x icp das converters that work just not listed, I don't have them unfortunately.
.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
kernel-4.4.4-301.fc23.x86_64

How reproducible:


Steps to Reproduce:
1.
2.
3.

Actual results:


Expected results:


Additional info:
Can you provide the output of 'lsusb -vv' please?

Bus 003 Device 012: ID 1b5c:0104  
Device Descriptor:
  bLength                18
  bDescriptorType         1
  bcdUSB               2.00
  bDeviceClass            0 
  bDeviceSubClass         0 
  bDeviceProtocol         0 
  bMaxPacketSize0         8
  idVendor           0x1b5c 
  idProduct          0x0104 
  bcdDevice           10.00
  iManufacturer           1 ICPDAS
  iProduct                2 I-7561U USB Serial Converter
  iSerial                 3 00YVVA8I
  bNumConfigurations      1
  Configuration Descriptor:
    bLength                 9
    bDescriptorType         2
    wTotalLength           32
    bNumInterfaces          1
    bConfigurationValue     1
    iConfiguration          0 
    bmAttributes         0x80
      (Bus Powered)
    MaxPower              100mA
    Interface Descriptor:
      bLength                 9
      bDescriptorType         4
      bInterfaceNumber        0
      bAlternateSetting       0
      bNumEndpoints           2
      bInterfaceClass       255 Vendor Specific Class
      bInterfaceSubClass    255 Vendor Specific Subclass
      bInterfaceProtocol    255 Vendor Specific Protocol
      iInterface              2 I-7561U USB Serial Converter
      Endpoint Descriptor:
        bLength                 7
        bDescriptorType         5
        bEndpointAddress     0x81  EP 1 IN
        bmAttributes            2
          Transfer Type            Bulk
          Synch Type               None
          Usage Type               Data
        wMaxPacketSize     0x0040  1x 64 bytes
        bInterval               0
      Endpoint Descriptor:
        bLength                 7
        bDescriptorType         5
        bEndpointAddress     0x02  EP 2 OUT
        bmAttributes            2
          Transfer Type            Bulk
          Synch Type               None
          Usage Type               Data
        wMaxPacketSize     0x0040  1x 64 bytes
        bInterval               0
can't get device qualifier: Resource temporarily unavailable
can't get debug descriptor: Resource temporarily unavailable
Device Status:     0x0000
  (Bus Powered)

I added a patch that adds support for the devices to the scratch build below.  When it is finished would you please test it and see if the device works out of the box?

http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13297271
Tested, device works fine, no errors or wrong data during read/write operations.

(In reply to The Source from comment #4)
> Tested, device works fine, no errors or wrong data during read/write
> operations.

Thanks for testing.  The patch has been sent upstream and it will be in the next build done in Fedora.

bugs.title: kernel-4.4.4-301.fc23.x86_64 causes system to hang on boot

bugzilla.short_desc: kernel-4.4.4-301.fc23.x86_64 causes system to hang on boot

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1135664
screenshot of failed boot

Description of problem: After current fedora updates to kernel-4.4.4-301 the system hangs on boot.  It initially halts on defining drive devices, then progresses a page and fails.  A soft reboot also fails (the system will not reboot.  The only way to get back into the system is to hard boot with the previous kernel (4.4.3-300).  I have checked xfsprogs and it is version 4.3.0-1.fc23.  I had read that earlier versions have a conflict with this kernel.  The problem occurs on both my Dell computers with identical configurations.  The processors are i7-3770 CPU @ 3.40GHz.  The desktop on both is KDE Plasma 5.5.5.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):4.4.4-310


How reproducible:


Steps to Reproduce:
1.Boot with kernel-4.4.4-301
2.System hangs during boot
3. Hard boot into previous kernel required to boot properly.

Actual results: System hangs during boot


Expected results: System should boot normally into desktop GUI


Additional info:

of interest:
http://jwboyer.livejournal.com/52090.html

I have the exact same issue as above and tried the suggested fix found on the page provided by the first commenter to no success.  Boot with an older kernel (4.2.3), and It ill prompt for my encryption passphrase after a few seconds and continue as normal.  With the new one (4.4.4), it hangs at the line "switched to clocksource: tsc".  I have removed all peripherals to no effect.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks

The links below also reference problems with this kernel - though it seems the culprit may be dracut.  I have tried the solutions offered by users to no avail.  Let us know if it works for you.  Kernel 4.4.5-300  is currently in testing so hopefully that will provide a remedy when a stable version is released.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1313025

http://forums.fedoraforum.org/showthread.php?t=309076
I too had found those posts, but they did not resolve my issue.  Thanks for the reply

Same problem here (with i686 kernel). I've tried install testing kernel 4.4.5 but problem remains even with this version. Boot hangs with message "A start job is running for Waif for Plymouth Boot Screen to Quit", reboot via ctrl+alt+del hangs on "A stop job is running for The KDE login manager".

However for me it seems like problem with GPU. "journalctl --boot=-1" shows "X server startup timeout, terminating" and /var/log/Xorg.0.log.old ends with "xfree86: Adding drm device /dev/dri/card0" while boot with kernel 4.4.3 Xorg.0.log continues with "xfree86: Adding drm device /dev/dri/card1".

Problem appears only one of my notebooks, Thinkpad T400 with integrated Intel GM45 and discrete AMD RV620. Old atom netbook and new Thinkpad L450 (with integrated Broadwell HD Graphics 5500 and discrete R5 M240) works without problem.
It sounds like the kernel is booting up but graphics are not starting. Can you switch to a console and collect the journal logs?

Created attachment 1136300
Log of failed boot

(In reply to Petr Bartos from comment #7)
> Created attachment 1136300 [details]
> Log of failed boot

Unfortunately when boot hangs, it is not possible to switch terminals (last boot message is displayed on all screens). Therefore I guess journalctl --boot=-1 is the only thing I can provide?

BTW I've tried to disable discrete GPU in bios and both 4.4.4 and 4.4.5 kernels are now booting without problems. So it is definitely some problem with radeon driver.
Okay that's good to know. It will be good to get confirmation from the other reporters to see if it's the same issue for everyone
http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13347691 There was a known issue with the radeon driver, can you test this build when it fnishes?
I am unfamiliar  with koji but know how to build src.rpms. Could you point me to what I need to do to get the package?  Thank

I have a Radeon R9 380 R9 380 4G LE 4GB 256-Bit GDDR5 HDCP Ready CrossFireX Support card so it may be that your kernel package has a problem with Radeon cards.  Let us know when the build is ready for download so we can test it.  Thanks.

Created attachment 1136681
Log of failed boot - radeonfix

Created attachment 1136682
Xorg log - radeonfix

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #10)
> http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13347691 There was a
> known issue with the radeon driver, can you test this build when it fnishes?

Unfortunately same result with patched kernel
I have the same problem also Radeon Graphics(Radeon R7 M260/M265)

Well kernel-4.4.5-300.fc23.x86_64.rpm has fixed my problem.  It boots fine with no issues.  I downloaded your rpms from here:
http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=743760
Downloading and installing before the kernel the devel, core, headers, modules and modules-extra packages and last of all the kernel.
Thank you for your work on this Laura Abbott.

I see a previous comment was lost.  I also have a Radeon card a Radeon R9 380 4G LE 4GB 256-Bit GDDR5 HDCP Ready CrossFireX Support ATX Video Card to be precise.  So if the problem was with the Radeon card in kernel 4.4.4-301 then 4.4.5-300 resolves it.

Okay, so it fixed it for one person. Thanks for testing. That fix should be showing up in 4.4.6 which should be coming up for testing tomorrow or Thursday.

There is apparently yet another radeon fix. http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13356645 is building with just the 2nd fix. Please test that when it finishes if the previous build did not work for you.
Same problem here with 4.4.4-301. Update to 4.4.5-300 @updates-testing, works like a charm.
The fix worked for me as well.  I am running a Lenovo E460 with a Radeon R7 M360 2GB.  Thanks for the fix Laura!

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #19)
> Okay, so it fixed it for one person. Thanks for testing. That fix should be
> showing up in 4.4.6 which should be coming up for testing tomorrow or
> Thursday.
> 
> There is apparently yet another radeon fix.
> http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13356645 is building with
> just the 2nd fix. Please test that when it finishes if the previous build
> did not work for you.

Perfect, "radeonfix2" is working. In which kernel version is it expected to be released? In order to know which update to avoid for now. Thanks for fix.

With 4.4.6 on Thinkpad L450 (integrated Broadwell HD Graphics 5500, discrete R5 M240 - the one which was working without problems with 4.4.4 and 4.4.5) I'm encountering strange "micro freezes", typically when opening new window (including tooltips) or changing resolution (in Plasma 5). bugs.title: On Lenovo T500 boot hangs on lcpci

bugzilla.short_desc: On Lenovo T500 boot hangs on lcpci

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
Fedora 23 does not come up on a T500 with latest Fedora 23 kernel 4.4.4-301


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): 4.4.4-301


How reproducible:
Install the named kernel on a Lenovo T500 (probably similar) on Fedora23 


Steps to Reproduce:
1. Update kernel to 4.4.4-301
2. Reboot

Actual results:
System does not come up. Remote execution using my own means (openvenus, see on sourceforge), not depending on other stuff like ssh, shows, that scripts are hanging waiting for lspci to finish, which in turn is in an "open" system call on /sys/bus/pci/devices/0000:01:00.0/config
which is booted with 4.4.3-300
00:01.0 PCI bridge: Intel Corporation Mobile 4 Series Chipset PCI Express Graphics Port (rev 07)


Expected results:
system comes up and is usable

Additional info:
this is the Laptop of my wife. I think when things are not getting better i'll buy some Windows license.

The last lines i see during boot on the screen:
Starting Show Plymouth Boot Screen
Starting dracut initqueue hook

then nothing happens anymore.
Can you get any kind of dmesg output from whatever you are using to trace the calls? Does any earlier kernel work? Please also share the full output of lspci from your system.

As i wrote, with kernel 4.4.3-300 and earlier ones the system comes up. Obtaining an lspci output is not possible with 4.4.4-301. strace shows, that lspci hangs in the system call open with /sys/bus/pci/devices/0000:01:00.0/config as first argument.
So the attached lspci output is obtained with 4.4.3-300 booted.

Created attachment 1136373
lspci output obtained with older kernel booted

Created attachment 1136374
dmesg output in the status when the system does not come up with 4.4.4-301

Created attachment 1136375
strace of lspci in the hanging status when booted with 4.4.4-301
Additional Info: When in the hanging status, the laptop must be reset hardly by holding down the power button for several seconds. Even reboot -nf does not work.
There was a known Radeon issue, can you please test http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13347691
There were actually two issues. If that one doesn't work, please test http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13356645 as well

The 2nd fix is required, then the system comes up normally again. Thank you. The only thing that looks unusual to me is, that the "plymouth boot screen" bubble does not show after the display has switched to the higher resolution.

What i would like to know, why this had to be broken.
kernel-4.4.6-300.fc23 has been submitted as an update to Fedora 23. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2016-02ed08bf15

bugs.title: CVE-2016-3134 kernel: netfilter: missing bounds check in ipt_entry structure

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-3134 kernel: netfilter: missing bounds check in ipt_entry structure

long_desc.thetext:
In the mark_source_chains function (net/ipv4/netfilter/ip_tables.c) it is possible for a user-supplied ipt_entry structure to have a large next_offset field. This field is not bounds checked prior to writing a counter value at the supplied offset.

Proposed fix:

patch v1 message: http://marc.info/?l=netfilter-devel&m=145757134822741&w=2
patch v2  thread: http://marc.info/?t=145757149500006&r=1&w=2

patch v2 message: http://marc.info/?l=netfilter-devel&m=145762719008418&w=2
patch v2  thread: (none yet) http://marc.info/?l=netfilter-devel&r=4&b=201603&w=2

CVE request and assignment:

http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/581
http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/619

Audit done by netfilter team found several related bugs, patches to better validate rulesets are currently queued in pablos nf-next tree upstream (use "parent" link to cycle to next one - there are 17 additional patches):

https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/pablo/nf-next.git/commit/?id=d7591f0c41ce3e67600a982bab6989ef0f07b3ce

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1317384]

Statement:

This issue affects the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6. This issue is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates, as user namespaces which the flaw affects are not supported in these products. For additional information, refer to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle: https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata/.

This issue affects the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and MRG-2. Future Linux kernel updates for the respective releases might address this issue.
*** Bug 1320138 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
kernel-4.4.6-300.fc23 has been pushed to the Fedora 23 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
kernel-4.4.6-200.fc22 has been pushed to the Fedora 22 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
kernel-4.5.0-302.fc24 has been pushed to the Fedora 24 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
kernel-4.5.0-302.fc24 has been pushed to the Fedora 24 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

I'd prefer if the maintainers of those trees can take care of picking these patches up since I don't know how to do this.

All changes are now in rhel7.git .  I only see a problem with older
rhel7 kernels (where netfilter rule blob is percpu), if 7.1 and 7.2 releases need a zstream please let me know.

If there are any other questions feel free to ping me.

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  MRG for RHEL-6 v.2

Via RHSA-2016:1883 https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2016-1883.html

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2016:1847 https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2016-1847.html

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2016:1875 https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2016-1875.html

bugs.title: CVE-2016-3135 kernel: netfilter: size overflow in x_tables

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-3135 kernel: netfilter: size overflow in x_tables

long_desc.thetext:
An integer overflow vulnerability was found in xt_alloc_table_info, which on 32-bit systems can lead to small structure allocation and a copy_from_user based heap corruption.

Proposed fix:

patch v1 message: http://marc.info/?l=netfilter-devel&m=145757136822750&w=2
patch v1  thread: http://marc.info/?t=145757149700001&r=1&w=2

patch v2 message: http://marc.info/?l=netfilter-devel&m=145800533813758&w=2 (in netfilter-devel)
patch v2 message: http://marc.info/?l=linux-netdev&m=145800538413781&w=2 (in linux-netdev)

CVE request and assignment:

http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/581
http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/619

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1317387]

Statement:

This issue does not affect the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6, as the code with the flaw is not present in the products listed.

This issue does not affect the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and MRG-2, as 32-bit versions of the products listed are not shipped by the Red Hat.
*** Bug 1320143 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bugs.title: CVE-2016-3156 kernel: ipv4: denial of service when destroying a network interface

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-3156 kernel: ipv4: denial of service when destroying a network interface

long_desc.thetext:
Destroy of network interface with huge number of ipv4 addresses
keeps rtnl_lock for a very long time (up to hour).
It blocks many network related operations,
including for example creation of new incoming ssh connections.

The problem is especially important for containers,
container owner have enough permission to enable this trigger
and then can block network access on whole host node.

Upstream fix:

http://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/davem/net-next.git/commit/?id=fbd40ea0180a2d328c5adc61414dc8bab9335ce2

References:

http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/643

CVE assignment:

http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/647

Acknowledgements:

Name: the Virtuozzo kernel team, Solar Designer (Openwall)

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1318270]

Statement:

This issue affects the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6. This has been rated as having Moderate security impact and is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates, as the Linux containers which the flaw affects are not supported in these products. For additional information, refer to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle: https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata/.

This issue affects the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and MRG-2. Future Linux kernel updates for the respective releases might address this issue.

the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

[bug automatically created by: add-tracking-bugs]

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1318172,1318270

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for CVE-2016-3156

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

product security believes this flaw should be handled as 1) the fix is quite trivial 2) it was shown that in certain configurations (many containers) the lock could be held up to an hour and 3) the patch worth the inclusion to the kernel tree given all the redhat containers-related initiatives.

for now the patch was not yet accepted to the mainline kernel tree by Linus, but resides in David Miller's net-next git: http://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/davem/net-next.git/commit/?id=fbd40ea0180a2d328c5adc61414dc8bab9335ce2
Fixed in Fedora git on all branches.

bug.title: kernel-4.4.4-301.fc23.x86_64 causes system to hang on boot
On Lenovo T500 boot hangs on lcpci
CVE-2016-3156 kernel: ipv4: denial of service when destroying a network interface [fedora-all]
CVE-2016-3156 kernel: ipv4: denial of service when destroying a network interface
CVE-2016-3134 kernel: netfilter: missing bounds check in ipt_entry structure
CVE-2016-3135 kernel: netfilter: size overflow in x_tables [fedora-all]
CVE-2016-3135 kernel: netfilter: size overflow in x_tables
